Silhouette: Under ground truth labels, this region forms a clear continuous band. K-Means forcibly splits the band into relatively discrete block-like clusters, whereas GMM and Spectral clustering preserve the continuous transition structure.
Davies-Bouldin: This region does not consist of two well-separated clusters but instead represents a semantically continuous feature manifold. The centroid-based assumption of K-Means disrupts manifold continuity, while GMM and Spectral clustering better respect the intrinsic geometry of the data.

Silhouette: This area exhibits the strongest label mixing under ground truth. K-Means induces noticeable label reassignment, while GMM and Spectral clustering remain highly overlapped.
Davies-Bouldin: The region corresponds to a high-density, low-discriminability subspace where class-specific signals are weak. Clustering behavior is therefore driven primarily by density rather than semantic boundaries, making stable partitioning difficult for all methods.

Silhouette: A relatively stable, high-density cluster is formed across all clustering methods. Spectral clustering shows the clearest boundary, while K-Means and GMM display minor mixing.
Davies-Bouldin: This region is well separated from the rest of the embedding space, indicating strong feature discriminability. Spectral clustering reinforces internal consistency by exploiting local neighborhood connectivity.

Silhouette: A small isolated tail structure remains detached across all four subplots, with minimal variation in clustering assignments.
Davies-Bouldin: These samples lie in a low-density, weakly connected region of the embedding space, forming an outlying manifold branch. All clustering methods tend to preserve its structural independence.

Silhouette: Under ground truth labels, the distribution is highly dispersed. K-Means compresses the region into a relatively compact cluster, whereas GMM and Spectral clustering exhibit greater internal spread.
Davies-Bouldin: This category inherently has high intra-class variability. K-Means enforces compactness by minimizing within-cluster variance, while GMM and Spectral clustering more faithfully reflect the non-uniform distribution of the data.
